loans.name: Naddy

texts.en:
Nothing could be wrong with small beginnings, as Naddy D., 31, would substantiate.  Naddy is a Community Partner of CCT* in Dasmarinas, Cavite, where she and her husband, Eleomar, raise their family. Eleomar is a tricycle driver. They have two children, one of whom is in elementary school while the younger one is not yet attending school. Naddy reached only high school, but it does not mean she cannot perform well as a micro-entrepreneur.

At present, Naddy runs her own ready-to-wear (RTW) business. She started small, with her house as her working space. She would buy clothes which she thought would fit the taste of her potential customers, and sell them to friends, neighbors, and business connections. She also does direct selling, offering her customers products from beauty brands, such as Avon and MSE.  With these entrepreneurial efforts and the daily tricycle operation of Eleomar, their family earns around Php12,000 per month.

To help her grow her business, Naddy decided to borrow Php16,000. She plans to use this money to buy additional quantities of the affordable, yet quality, products that her customers look for. She knows that having enough capital on hand will enable her to purchase the orders for her valued customers even without initial down payments.

Naddy is surely not exempted from the challenges of direct selling, such as delayed payments. But rather than focusing on her problems, Naddy instead focuses on making her business grow from a small beginning to big time growth. She hopes to have her own commercial space where more potential customers are within an arm’s reach. She also desires to have her own tricycle. For her family, she desires good health and a sustained education for her children.

As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she received.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase additional quantities of quality clothes

loans.name: Pharn

texts.en: Pharn N., 51, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Prey Veng Province, Cambodia, an area known as one of the largest rice producing regions in Cambodia. N. is a housewife while her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of USD 2.5 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD 44 on food and USD 20 on other necessary expenses. N. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase a motorbike for the family's use. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for the family's use

loans.name: Jamila's Group

texts.en:
Jamila is 38 years old and married to L. A., who has operated a spice-selling business for the last 20 years. He sells spices to different grocery stores and general stores in the city. People know him as an honest and hardworking businessman who always fulfills his commitments.
 
Jamila lives in Okara, which is a small city in Pakistan known for its agriculture industry. She lives there in the area of Sheikh Basti with her family in a two-room brick house. Jamila works with her husband in his business. She packs the spices in plastic bags and sells to people in her community. She has given birth to five children. Her eldest son works in the vegetable market as a vegetable vendor, while the other children attend local school. 

Jamila has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to buy spices in bulk to improve her husband’s business. The loan will enable her husband to increase his sales and to fulfill orders on time. She is a regular loan user of Asasah, and this is her third loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained good behavior and never missed any meeting.

loans.use: To buy spices for selling

loans.name: Eng

texts.en: Eng S., 34, resides in Prey Veng Province, Cambodia, an area known as one of the largest rice-producing regions in Cambodia. S. is employed at a local garment factory, earning an income of USD 5 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 44 on food and USD 5 on other necessary expenses. S. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase an ice-cream box and a motorbike for her brother to start a business. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy an icebox and a motorbike

loans.name: Hilaria's Group

texts.en:
Hilaria B. is from the village of Guayabal, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 48 years old. Hilaria is the group leader of a nine-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Hilaria is married and has four school-age children. To make a living, Hilaria owns and operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Hilaria has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP when she sells one of her raised pigs. In 2007, Hilaria joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Hilaria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. Hilaria is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the 11th loan taken out by Hilaria from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Sor

texts.en: Sor S., 51, is married and resides with her husband and child in Prey Veng Province, Cambodia, an area known as one of the largest rice-producing regions in Cambodia. S. is a housewife while her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of USD 5 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD 30 on food and USD 10 on other necessary expenses. S. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase rice to stock and sell when the price is good. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy rice to stock for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase farm inputs, such as seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Richel

texts.en:
Richel C. is from the village of Barucboc, Quezon, Isabela. She is 33 years old. Richel is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Richel owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Richel has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 35000 PHP per harvest.

In 2009, Richel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Richel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 18,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. Richel is requesting a new loan of 23000 PHP, which will be used to pay for services to increase crop yield. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Richel from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To pay for services to increase crop yield

loans.name: Batgerel

texts.en: Batgerel, 40, is married and lives with his wife and three children in Suhbaatar province of Mongolia. They live in a ger, Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in someone's backyard. His wife is unemployed and all of his children attend a local secondary school. Batgerel owns some livestock in the countryside. He started a woodcraft business in 2010. He makes chairs, tables and ger structure parts, such as doors and walls. He needs to gain more experience and collect more equipment and tools for his business. Batgerel has been working hard to make more profit from his business and buy the necessary equipment. He is a hardworking and modest person who says, " I am planning to buy land and start building our own home". He is requesting a loan of 600,000 MNT to purchase more equipment and materials for his business.

loans.use: To purchase more equipment and materials

loans.name: Bayarjavkhlan

texts.en:
Bayarjavkhlan is 31 years old and lives with her father and husband in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her family lives in a small house, in the outer ger districts of the city. But she and her husband only live at this home in winter because they plant trees on their land in Selenge province during other seasons. 

Bayarjavkhlan and her husband support their family by planting, growing, and selling trees. Every year, they plant from 800,000 to 1,200,000 pines, firs, maples, seabuckthorns, currants and cedars in association with cooperatives on their land. In addition, they replant 20 to 35 hectares of trees in forests per year. They also rehabilitate 20 to 30 hectares of land every year. She is requesting a 700,000 MNT loan to purchase a new type of tree seeds.

Bayarjavkhlan said “I like my job and I think planting trees is a good deed. So in the future, I‘ll plant a lot of trees on the land.” She wants to improve her business with this loan and then she wants to be able to build her own house.

loans.use: To purchase a new type of tree seeds

loans.name: Zahida's Group

texts.en:
Zahida lives in Lahore, which is the second largest city of Pakistan and known for its history and culture. She lives there in the area of Daata town with her family in a 2 room brick house. She moved here 25 years ago. 
Her husband’s name is M. S., and he is a rickshaw driver. He provides transport services to his clients. She is the mother of 2 daughters and a son. Her son works in a private organization and her daughters are studying in a local school. 
Zahida operates a clothes business to financially support her family. She buys clothes from AnarkA., which is a famous clothes market of Lahore, and  sell to her customers and generates good income. 
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for the betterment of her embroidery business. With the loan, she will buy embroidery material, such as beads and colored thread, and clothes in bulk, which will allow her to fulfill the orders on time and make extra profits. 
She has been operating this business for the past 20 years and hopes that it will grow further after making an investment in it. 
She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit behavior and never missed any meeting. 
Note: “In the photo, the lady who is showing her embroidered dress is Zahida”.

loans.use: To buy embroidery material for embroidery business

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia lives in the historic city of Lahore, Pakistan.   Lahore is the second largest city of Punjab and known for its history, gardens, culture and food.  She has lived in the area named Ismail Nagar with her family in a 2-room brick house for the past 12 years. She is the mother of 2 sons and 2 daughters. All of them are enrolled in a local school and are getting their education. Razia is hopeful that they will complete their education and become successful in life. She is 32 years old and married to M. A., who is an embroidery expert. He operates his shop in the market and offers his clients his embroidery skills. 
Razia is also a caring and supportive lady by nature. She supports her family financially by selling clothes. She purchases clothes from the AnarkA. and Azam markets, which are famous clothes markets in the city of Lahore, and sells to her neighborhood clients for profit.  

Razia has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, to further improve her husband’s business. With the loan, he will purchase clothes and embroidery material, such as beads, colored thread, etc., in bulk, and will also hire a worker who will assist him in completing his work. 
He has been operating this business for the past 10 years.  Razia is confident about his business growth after the  loan investment. 
She is a regular loan user of Asasah, and this is her 5th loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit behavior and never missed any meeting.

loans.use: To buy clothes and embroidery material for embroidery business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase farm inputs, such as fertilizers

loans.name: Rema

texts.en:
Rema is from the town of Banga. She is 40 years old and married. She has 2 children, aged 17 and 9. To make a living, Rema owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Rema works hard to build her business.

Rema joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rema has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI.  Rema is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Ruby

texts.en:
Ruby N. is from the town of Banga. She is 51 years old. Ruby is married and has 3 children. To make a living, Ruby owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Ruby also helps her husband maintain their rice farm.

Ruby joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ruby has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Ruby is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional piglets, feed and vitamins. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her family financially. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional piglets, feed and vitamins

loans.name: Zahida's Group

texts.en:
Zahida is a very supportive lady and a caring housewife. She stays at home and fulfills her household responsibilities efficiently. She has very good administrative abilities and handles the expenses of her home with great responsibility.  She also does embroidery part time for her neighborhood clients to help her husband financially.  She lives with her family in a three room brick house in Lahore, Pakistan. Lahore is the 2nd largest city of Pakistan and known for its history and culture. She has been living there in the area of Daata town for past 18 years. She is the mother of 2 sons and 4 daughters. Her sons work in a factory for a meager income and her daughters stay at home and help their mother in her household work. 

Her husband’s name is M. S., and he manufactures furniture to order. His furniture showroom is located in the market, and he has a good number of clients who give him good orders of furniture.  Zahida has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, to further expand her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy wood, nails and furniture polisher, etc., which will help him produce good quality furniture.  He will display it in his show room for selling. He has been in this business for the past 10 years, and Zahida is hopeful that, after the loan investment, his business will improve further and so will the living standard of the family as well. 

This is her 2nd loan application from Asasah.  In the previous loan year, she established a good credit behavior and never missed any meeting.

loans.use: To buy woods, nails and furniture polisher for furniture making business

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
At 62, Anita still desires to help provide for her family. She still works on the farm, planting and harvesting rice crops. She does her best to keep the farm productive. She wants to improve her business and provide better living conditions for her family.

Anita needs seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. She is requesting a loan of 16,000 Philippine pesos which she will use to buy what she needs for the farm. Anita is hopeful that this loan will help improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Charles Chege

texts.en:
Charles, age 32, has practiced farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 14 years. He and his wife, Rebecah Nduta, have two children.

He was introduced to KADET Ltd. by his friend and this will be his fourth loan. He paid off all his previous loans regularly and promptly. He plans to use the loan amount to buy fertilizer and seedlings. 

In future, Charles hopes to practice large-scale farming.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seedlings for his farm

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene M. is from the village of Barinaut, Iligan City. She is 34 years old. Arlene is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Arlene owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products, such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods & toothpaste in the local community. Arlene has been engaged in her business for over 11 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Arlene joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Arlene has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Arlene is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell, like beverages & canned goods. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Arlene from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell, like beverages & canned goods

location.town: Barina-ut, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Samina's Group

texts.en:
Samina has been living in the area of Daata Nagar, Lahore, for the past 16 years with her family in a 2-room brick house. Lahore is Pakistan’s 2nd largest city and also known for its history and culture.  
Samina is 38 years old, married to M. A., and has 2 children. Both are enrolled in a local school and getting their education. 
Her husband has been involved in the furniture-making business for the last 10 years. His showroom is located in the market and he makes good quality furniture. 
Samina herself is a housewife.  She prefers to stay at home and take care of her household responsibilities. She is an active and supportive lady and takes care of her family very well.  She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for the expansion of her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy wood, nails, and furniture polish to make larger quantities of furniture. This should help him to fulfill larger orders on time.  Samina is very confident that her husband will make good use of the loan and will successfully be able to expand his business.
This is Samina's 2nd loan application with Asasah.   In the previous loan year, she has proved herself a responsible client by paying her installments on time and attending every meeting.

loans.use: To buy wood, nails and furniture polisher for furniture making business

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia grows rice for a living. She and her husband are both farmers. They cultivate their land to plant and harvest rice crops. They sell their harvest to rice traders.

Delia is a mother of 5 children. Her eldest child is 18 years old, while the youngest is only 6. All her five children go to school. Delia said she and her husband work hard to sustain their family, especially the children's education. It is their dream to see their children succeed in life.

Delia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services. She is requesting a loan of 8000 PHP, which she will use to buy seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: John Ruo

texts.en:
John is 32 years old and married to Martha Njeri. They have one child. For the last two years, John has run a retail shop in Ndunyu Njeru town. He also does small-scale farming on the side.  

John was introduced to KADET LTD by a field officer and this will be his fourth loan. He has repaid all of his previous loans well and in good time. John will use this loan to buy fertilizer and seedlings to plant during this growing season. In the future, John hopes to expand both of his business and increase his income.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seedlings

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 45 years old, married and supports her family by operating two business ventures: fish vending/dried fish vending and ready to wear clothes. She lives in Ilog, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2006 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 4,000. Josephine is borrowing PHP 10,000 to fund operations. This will be her eighth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 5,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Josephine aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org.

loans.use: To fund her dried fish business

loans.name: Catherine Wambui

texts.en:
Catherine, age 49, has been farming and keeping poultry in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 25 years. She and her husband, Mwaura Kimani, have two children.  

She was introduced to KADET Ltd. by her friend and this will be her first loan. She plans to use the loan amount to buy iron sheets and timber to build a house for keeping poultry.

In future, Catherine hopes to increase both her farming and poultry-rearing efforts to large-scale concerns, thus increasing her income.

loans.use: To buy iron sheets and timber to build a house for keeping poultry

loans.name: Peter Njoroge

texts.en:
Peter is 25 years old and married to Grace Njambi. They have two children. For the past two years, Peter has practiced farming in Ndunyu Njeru town. 

A friend introduced Peter to KADET LTD and this will be his fourth loan. He has repaid all his previous loans well and in good time. Peter plans to use this loan to buy fertilizer and seedlings. In the future, Peter hopes to add dairy to his farm.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seedlings

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia L. is a married woman who lives in Brooke's Point, Palawan. She earns her living by operating a fish vending business.  Her husband Efifanio, who is 60 years old, works as a driver to earn his living.  They have seven children who are between 20 and 42 years old. Virginia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 19 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Virginia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 20th loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,500 to buy fresh fish so that she can continue to save up for future family needs. Virginia L. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org.

loans.use: To purchase a stock of fresh fish

loans.name: David Waithaka

texts.en:
David, age 24, has been distributing water in Naivaha town using his donkey and cart for the last three years. He and his wife, Esther Wangui, have one child.  

He was introduced to KADET Ltd. by his friend and this will be his second loan. He paid off his first loan of Kshs 10,000 regularly and promptly. He plans to use the loan amount to buy a new motorcycle for transportation as he seeks to upgrade his business and to venture into new endeavors.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle to upgrade his business and to venture into new endeavors

loans.name: Arceli's Group

texts.en:
Arceli B. is from the village of Cabisera 25, Ilagan, Isabela. She is 46 years old. Arceli is the group leader of a 8-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Arceli B..

Arceli is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Arceli owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Arceli has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Arceli joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Arceli has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future. Arceli is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase breeding livestock. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Arceli from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase breeding livestock

loans.name: Stephen Chege

texts.en:
Stephen, age 45, has been in the motorcycle transport business for the last three years. He also has his own rental houses in Naivasha town. He and his wife, Mary Wanjiku, have four children.

He was introduced to KADET Ltd. by his friend and this will be his second loan. He paid off his first loan of Kshs 63,000 promptly and regularly. He plans to use the loan amount to buy materials for building rental houses on his piece of land.

In future, Stephen hopes to buy a car which he will operate as a taxi.

loans.use: To buy materials for building rental houses on his piece of land

loans.name: Moreen

texts.en: Moreen is a thirty-two year-old, hardworking woman living in her own house in Kasese, Uganda.  For four years she has been selling clothes, and with the income generated, she has been able to sustain her family and also restock her business.  She has a challenge of limited capital to meet the demands of her customers, and her dream is to set up a boutique.  Moreen needs the loan to buy clothes to sell.

loans.use: Buying clothes to sell.

loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Nora is a married woman who lives in Ilog, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a general store. Her husband Rony, who is 43 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities. They have no children. Nora joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 14 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Nora has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 9,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 1/000 after paying her amortization and less expense, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 15th loan, she is borrowing PHP 14,000 to use as additional capital for her sari-sari store so that she can continue to save up for future expansion of her business. Nora is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org.

loans.use: Additional capital for her general store

loans.name: Lydia Muthoni

texts.en:
Lydia, age 26, has practised agriculture in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last six years. She and her husband, Joseph Gikonyo, have two children.  

She was introduced to KADET Ltd. by her friend and this will be her second loan. She off her first loan of Kshs 30,000 regularly and promptly. She plans to use the loan amount to buy seeds and fertilizer.

In future, Lydia hopes to practice large-scale farming.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer for her farm

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia is an entrepreneur from the town of Banga, South Cotabato. She is 57 years old and married. She has 12 children.  The younger ones are still going to school. 

Delia is engaged in rice farming. She also owns a piggery and poultry.  Aside from agricultural investments, she runs a sari-sari store as well. Delia does all these activities to provide for her big family. She said that it is not easy to sustain a big family like hers, but it gets lighter because she shares the burden with her husband.

Delia is in need of farm inputs, hog and poultry feeds. She is requesting a loan of 16000 PHP, which she will use to buy what she needs for her businesses. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to their house.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs, hog & poultry feeds

loans.name: Tederlita

texts.en:
Tederlita T. is from the village of Santa Felomina, Iligan City. She is 57 years old. Tederlita is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Tederlita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods and toothpaste in the local community. Tederlita has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Tederlita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Tederlita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and increase working capital. Tederlita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like beverages and canned goods. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Tederlita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell like beverages and canned goods

location.town: Santa Felomena, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Patrick Ngugi

texts.en:
Patrick is 39 years old, married to Beth Muthoni, and they have three children. He has operated his motorcycle in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last six years. Patrick was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend, and this will be his third loan. He repaid all of his previous loans well and in good time and plans to use this loan amount to buy a new motorcycle.

In the future, Patrick hopes to own a taxi to operate in Ndunyu Njeru.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle.

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira is a 51-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures:  a sari-sari (general) store and copra. She lives in the municipality of Brooke's Point, Palawan. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her sari-sari (general) store and copra businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average income of PHP 12,500. Elvira is now borrowing PHP 13,000 so that she could purchase more stock. This will be her 23rd loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Elvira aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org.

loans.use: To purchase more items to sell

loans.name: Eric

texts.en:
Eric is a rice farmer living in the town of Banga, South Cotabato. He is married and has 2 children; a 6-year-old, and an infant. Friends and neighbors describe Eric as a responsible person, be it in his family or business. Eric works hard to keep his rice crops healthy. He wants to be able to sell quality rice to his community. 

Eric joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eric has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Eric is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP,which will be used to purchase fertilizers and additional seeds. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for his children's tuition fees.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and additional seeds

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a 46-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a general store. She lives in Cauayan, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1992 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 3,000. Rose is borrowing PHP 19,500 to purchase more stocks to sell. This will be her 21st loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 16,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Rose aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. loans.name: Nila

texts.en:
Nila D. is from the village of Dist.1, San Manuel. She is 42 years old. Nila is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Nila owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Nila has been engaged in her business for over 17 years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Nila joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nila has successfully repaid a previous loan of 35,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Nila is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offerings. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Nila from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offerings

loans.name: Lucy Wanjeri

texts.en:
Lucy, 52 years old, has practised agriculture in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 25 years. She mainly plants potatoes which she later sells to her customers. Lucy was introduced to KADET LTD by her friend, and this will be her fourth loan. She has repaid all her previous loans well and in good time and plans to use this loan to buy seeds and fertilizer.

In the future, Lucy hopes to buy more land and practise large-scale farming.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Sandra

texts.en:
Sandra is a married woman who lives in Ilog, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a pig fattening business and a fishing business. Her husband Jerry, who is 46 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities. They have three children who are between 13 and 20 years old. Sandra joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1998 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 15 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Sandra has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 16th loan, she is borrowing PHP 22,000, which she intends to use as additional working capital so that she can continue to save up for future business expansion and her children's education. Sandra is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team on http://www.kiva.org

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Josphat Kingori

texts.en:
Josphat, who has practised mixed farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 20 years, is 39 years old, married to Tabitha Njeri, and they have three children. He was introduced to KADET LTD by one of our credit officers, and this will be his second loan. Josphat repaid his previous loan of Kshs 40,000 well and in good time, and plans to use this loan to buy four cows which he will sell later at a profit.

In the future, Josphat hopes to pursue large-scale farming.

loans.use: To buy four cows which he will sell later at a profit.

loans.name: Rita

texts.en: Rita B. is from the village of Mainit, Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 44 years old. Rita is single. To make a living, Rita makes and sells coco and wooden charcoal in the local community. Rita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2009, Rita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Rita is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional raw materials needed for making charcoal. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Rita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional raw materials needed for making charcoal

loans.name: Abdul

texts.en:
Abdul is a 56-year-old married man with eight children. He owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been in the honey business for two years; he started with 1,000,000 shillings but expanded to 1,500,000 shillings. 

His hardships are high transport costs, price fluctuation and increased rent. His vision is to supply the western region of the country, plus educating his children. Abdul intends to use the loan to buy jerrycans of honey for resale.

loans.use: Purchasing  jerrycans of honey for resale

The main source of income for the business comes from selling food and drinks and tending a canteen near the school. Melita has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month for these activities. In 2007, Melita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Melita is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Melita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. loans.name: Nasanairi

texts.en:
Nasanairi is a fifty-six-year-old married  man with six children living in his own house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been involved in a drug shop business for the last ten years. He desires to own a pharmacy and educate his children.

Nasanairi intends to use the loan to buy pharmaceutical drugs to sell.

loans.use: Buying pharmaceutical drugs to sell

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna M. is from the village of Panghiwaan, Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 47 years old. Myrna is married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Myrna owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from making and selling snacks like rice and cassava cakes in the local community. Myrna has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Myrna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Myrna is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients like eggs & flour, needed to make products for sale.  This will be the 1st loan taken out by Myrna from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: David Mukira

texts.en:
David has been selling fish in Naivasha town for the last two years.  He is 46 years old, married to Emmah Wanja, and they have two children.  

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his third loan. He paid back his previous loans well and in good time. He is planning to renovate his food stall and buy more utensils with the loan.

In future, David hopes to turn his fish stall into a restaurant selling different types of food.

loans.use: To renovate his food stall and buy more utensils.

loans.name: Medius

texts.en:
Medius is a thirty-four-year-old single female renting a house in Kasese, Uganda. She has been selling food for the last three years starting by selling tomatoes in the market. Now she sells maize, beans and groundnuts. Her hardship is high transport costs and price fluctuations while her vision is  to own an established  food store.

Medius needs the loan to buy maize, beans and groundnuts for sale.

loans.use: Buying maize, beans and groundnuts

loans.name: Felipe

texts.en:
Felipe lives in the town of Banga, South Cotabato, with his family. He is engaged in farming. He cultivates his land to plant and harvest rice crops. Felipe works hard to help his family financially. He does his best to improve his business and earn better.

Felipe joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Felipe has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Felipe is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds and fertilizers. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his business.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Khalida's Group

texts.en:
Khalida lives in Faisalabad which is Pakistan’s third largest city and known for its textile industry. She lives there in a 2-room brick house with her family in the area of Barkatpura. She moved here 10 years ago. She is 46 years old and is a widow who has a 21-year-old son who works in a private company for a reasonable income. 

After the death of her husband, Khalida had to work to support her family. She started a clothes-selling business. She takes orders from her neighborhood clients and fills them by purchasing the clothes from different shops in the city. Because Faisalabad is famous for its textiles, Khalida’s clothes-selling business is going very well. 

She is a very responsible person, and as a mother she is taking care of her family very well. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her clothes-selling business. With the loan, she will buy clothes in bulk which will allow her to offer more variety and to target a wider clientele. 

She has been operating this business for the past 5 years and hopes that the loan investment will bring positive changes to it and she will be able to save some profit from improved income for the marriage of her son in future. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 4th loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit behavior and never missed any meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with her hand raised is Khalida.

loans.use: To buy clothes for clothes-selling business

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is a thirty-six-year-old married woman with four children who owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. She has been selling second-hand clothes for the last ten years. She started with capital of 100,000 shillings and the business has been steadily growing such that she has been able to buy land and build a house out of the business profit. Her hardship is poor quality clothes and her vision is business expansion plus educating her children. Mary needs the loan to buy second-hand clothes for sale.

loans.name: Lourdes

Her previous loan of PHP 10,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Lourdes aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the Dungganon way.

Solomon is a 40-year-old married man with five children. He owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been in the salon business for over five years. He initially got money from farming to set up the salon. 

His vision is having an executive salon and educating his children. Solomon wants the loan to buy synthetic hair, weaves and oil for his salon.

loans.name: Vergilia

texts.en: Vergilia G. is from the village of Upper Cogon, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 53 years old. Vergilia is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Vergilia operates a specialized retail business. The main source of income for the business comes from dealing and direct selling clothing and beauty products from MSE, FULLERLIFE, EVER BILENA and NATASHA in the local community. Vergilia has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Vergilia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vergilia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. loans.name: Naseem's Group

texts.en:
Naseem has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to improve her business of selling clothes. She will utilize the loan money by buying clothes of different varieties that will allow her to offer more choice to her clients and to earn more profits. 

She lives in Faisalabad, which is famous for its textile industry. She lives there in a two-room brick house in the area of Barkatpura. She moved here 15 years ago with her family. 

Her husband is a mason by profession. Naseem has three sons. She couldn’t educate them due to financial constraints. Her eldest son follows the same profession of his father. He supports his father in his business. The son next to him is a car mechanic while the youngest one works as a salesman for a low income. 

Naseem is also a very good mother and a housewife. She takes care of her family very well and does her household responsibilities. She has two years of experience in her business and she is hopeful that a loan investment will prove beneficial for her business' further growth. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. In her previous loan year, she established good credit behavior and never missed a meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with her hand raised is Naseem.

loans.use: To buy clothes for a clothes selling business

loans.name: Christine

texts.en: Christine is a 52-year-old married woman with four children. She lives in her own house in Kasese, Uganda. She has been dealing in bananas for 15 years. She started her business with capital of 200,000 UGX and now her working capital is 1,000,000 UGX. Her main business challenge is price fluctuation and her vision is to be the leading supplier of bananas in the region. Christine is requesting a loan to buy bananas for resale.

loans.use: To buy bananas for resale

loans.name: Juliet Roxas' Group

texts.en:
Juliet R. is from the village of Alibago, Enrile, Cagayan. She is the leader of a six-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Juliet R. Group.
Juliet is 32 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising pigs for fattening and sale. Juliet has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 4,000 PHP when she sells one of her raised pigs.
In 2011, Juliet joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be her first from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Simion Njenga

texts.en:
Simion has operated his butcher shop in Naivasha town for the last 10 years.  He is 49 years old, married to Rebecca Wamaitha, and they have three children.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his fourth loan. He paid back all his previous loans well and in good time. He plans to use this loan to buy three cows and 10 sheep which he will raise for slaughter.

In future, Simion wants to build rental houses to diversify his income.

loans.use: To buy three cows and 10 sheep which he will raise for slaughter.

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita E. is from the village of Consolacion, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 49 years old, married and has two adult-aged children. To make a living, Rosita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling daily use products such as canned goods and junk foods in the local community. Rosita has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2010, Rosita joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Rosita is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell such as beverages and canned goods. This loan will be her second from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa is a married woman who lives in Bantayan, Cebu. She earns her living by fishing and fish vending. Her husband Rogelio, who is 46 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities. They have seven children who are between 2 and 19 years old. 

Elsa joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1997 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 15 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Elsa has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. 

Her previous loan of PHP 23,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 20,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 16th loan, she is borrowing PHP 23,000 to buy fishing gear and equipment so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children and purchase additional fishing boats. Elsa is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: To purchase fishing gear and equipment

He worked in a supermarket for three years and with his savings from his salary, he  was able to start a retail shop. His hardship is having too little capital plus price changes and his vision is owning a supermarket plus educating his children.

Daniel needs the money to buy cartons of mineral water and sugar for sale.

loans.name: Najma's Group

texts.en:
Najma comes from Faisalabad which is located in Punjab, Pakistan and is known for its textile industry. She has lived there in the area of Barkatpura with her family in a 2-room brick house for the past 20 years. She is married to I. who is 54 years old and doesn’t have a job. 

Najma is a talented lady who operates a boutique business at her home. She is expert in preparing plain and also embroidered dresses. She displays her work at her boutique and also supplies clothes to different clothing shops in the market.  She is the mother of three sons. Her eldest son works in a factory, and other two are drivers and provide transport services. 

Najma has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the expansion of her boutique business. With the loan, she will buy clothes and embroidery materials like beads, colored thread, etc to make larger quantity of clothes. She will also hire a worker who will assist her in completing her work. She is hopeful that her 5 years of business experience will help her in expanding her business on larger scale after the loan investment and her family will be able to have a better standard of life as a result. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 2nd loan application. In the previous loan year, she established a good credit behavior and never missed any meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with her hand raised is Najma.

loans.use: To buy clothes and embroidery material for boutique business

loans.name: Doolat's Group

texts.en:
Doolat is 43 years old and married with four children. She belongs to Kasur, which is a small city in Punjab in Pakistan and famous for its leather industry. She owns a small home of two rooms there and has been living in it with her family for the past 10 years.  She is a very supportive lady who knits sweaters to share the financial burden with her husband. In fact, knitting sweaters has become Doolat’s family business. All of her children operate the same business and earn very good profits. Their business grows well. especially in the winter season. They also supply the sweaters to other cities as well.  Her husband’s name is N. D. and he operates a loading business with his donkey cart. He puts the load on his donkey cart and delivers it from one place to another.  Doolat has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband. With the loan, he will buy a new donkey cart because his current cart has become rough and rotten in different areas. The new cart will help him do his work better by putting more loads on it. Doolat is hopeful that an investment will improve his business to a great extent and he will be able to make more profits. She is a new loan user of Asasah and hopes that it will prove to be a good decision for her.  

Note: “In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Doolat”.

loans.use: To buy a new donkey cart for loading business

loans.name: Julia

texts.en:
Julia is a married woman who lives in Bantayan, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a candle-making business and a general store. Her husband Romeo, who is 51 years old, works as a Brgy Tanod (police/security position) to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities. They have eight children who are between 6 and 28 years old. Julia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 18 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Julia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 22,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 19th loan, she is borrowing PHP 22,000, which she intends to use as additional capital for her candle-making business so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children and house repairs. Julia is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.
