texts.en:
Catherine has been selling stationary in Machakos town for 12 years and earns a profit margin of KES.15,000. The business is situated in town centre along syokimau road in Machakos town and she serves customers on a daily basis. She is 48 years, married to Festus K., and they are blessed with two children. 

She was introduced to KADET LTD by a client who is already a member of KADET, and she is applying for her first loan of KES. 30,000 to buy more stationery like toner, photocopier papers, pens, books .With the anticipated profit, she will plough it back into the business.

In future Catherine desires to grow her business and have financial stability,

loans.use: To buy toner, photocopier papers, pens, books and stationary

loans.name: Candido

texts.en:
Candido E. is from the village of Compra, Liloy, Zamboanga del Norte. He is 40 years old. Candido is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Candido is starting a business venture in the services sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing general services to local community members. Candido has been engaged in his business for over 6 years and earns approximately 15000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009,Candido joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Candido has successfully repaid a previous loan of 40000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Candido is requesting a new loan of 40000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Candido from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Delgermurun

texts.en:
Delgermurun is 34 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters, aged 10 and 12, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her family lives in a small house in the outer ger (tent) districts of the city. Her daughters attend primary school while her husband works as a plumber at a local company. 

Delgermurun supports her family by operating a clothing retail stall at Narantuul, the largest outdoor market in Mongolia. 

Delgermurun began her business in 2001 and now she has 2.5 million Mongolian Tugriks (MNT) in working capital. Over the past ten years she has gained a lot of experience and her moderate revenue has been used to maintain her standards of living. With this loan of 800,000 MNT, she wants to expand her clothing stall and purchase more clothing for the spring season from Ereen City, China. 

In the future, her family wants to buy their own car.

loans.use: To purchase clothing to sell for the spring season.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine to start her business

loans.name: Maura

texts.en:
Maura is a 53-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a fishing business and a fish vending business.  She lives in Bantayan, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fishing and fish vending businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 8,000. Maura is borrowing PHP 19,500 to purchase fishing gears and equipment. This will be her 14th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 13,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Maura aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org

loans.use: To purchase fishing gear and equipment

loans.name: Alymkan's Group

texts.en: Members of this group thank Kiva and its field partner in Kyrgyzstan for assisting underprivileged women who cannot turn to traditional banks. Alymkan D., 50, is a leader of this group. All members of this group are residents of a town called Tashkomur in Jalalabad province. She is married and doesn’t have any financial dependents. Alymkan’s husband is a chief engineer in a department of municipal property. Ten years ago, she herself initiated a business in cattle breeding and reselling. The capital of 10,000 soms came mainly from the money they’ve saved throughout all these years. They like this town because it’s peaceful and always safe to run a business. Alymkan, with help of her husband, takes care of the cattle and goes to a cattle yard once a month to resell them. She makes sure to have affordable prices for people who have even the least capacity to buy. Alymkan spends long hours in the mornings feeding the cattle, taking the cattle for a walk and making veterinarian checks. The income of 10,000 soms is enough to provide Alymkan and her husband with the basic needs. They also want to improve the house’s state. Therefore, Alymkan applied for this loan. She would like to purchase some furniture for the house. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase furniture

loans.name: Elenita

texts.en:
Elenita C. is from the village of Montol, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 33 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children.

Elenita owns and operates a business planting and harvesting corn for sale. She has been engaged in her business for 13 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month.

In April 2010, Elenita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise.

Elenita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP that will be used as capital to buy hypo (calcium hypochlorite, a disinfectant) for sale. This will be her third loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.


About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy hypo (calcium hypochlorite, a disinfectant) to sell.

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en:
Analiza is a married woman who lives in Bantayan, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a bakery/cake-making business and a food vending business. Her husband Eldifonso, who is 39 years old, works as a tricycle driver to earn his living. They have eight children who are between 4 and 16 years old. Analiza joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 18 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Analiza has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 29,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 15,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 19th loan, she is borrowing PHP 29,500 to buy a motorcycle for her bakery so that she can continue to save up for future education of her children and build a new house. Analiza is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle for her bakery business

loans.name: Baktygul's Group

texts.en:
This group is led by Baktygul. She is a successful and experienced farmer and wants to try her hand at cattle breeding. 

Baktygul S., 55, is the leader of this group. She lives in a small village called Kochkor, known as “sleepy little Kyrgyz village” for its quietness and calmness. She is the mother of three children in their twenties. Her daughter Eliza is a seamstress in a local sewing workshop, her oldest son Nurbek is a construction worker and the youngest is a college student in the capital of Bishkek. Baktygul’s husband is a high school teacher. Baktygul has a great deal of experience in farming. For 19 years she has been honing her skills in cultivating the land and harvesting rich crops of grains and vegetables. This year she focused mainly on growing potatoes: they are always in high demand and there are a variety of good strains to cultivate. Baktygul started this business when she went to work on the local farm. She managed to cover all her costs and even saved some money to buy electrical appliances for the house. Now the business brings in 4000 soms per month, and Baktygul has decided to try cattle breeding too. She’s quite skillful in it and always has friends who can advise her how to take good care of cattle. She would like to get this loan from Kiva and Mol Bulak Finance in order to purchase some cattle. 

       --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (being environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our lending team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle.

loans.name: Rogelio

texts.en:
Rogelio B. is from the village of Turod in Quezon, Isabela. He is 39 years old. Rogelio is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living Rogelio owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Rogelio has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 35000 PHP per harvest.

In 2011 Rogelio joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rogelio is requesting a new loan of 28000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rogelio from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay his children's tuition fees. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our field partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Jesusita

texts.en:
Jesusita is a 60-year-old widow who supports her family by operating a dressmaking/tailoring business. She lives in San Carlos City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2010 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her dressmaking/tailoring business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 5,600. Jesusita is borrowing PHP 10,000 to purchase raw materials. This will be her 19th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Jesusita aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org

loans.use: To purchase raw materials

loans.name: Mwashasha

texts.en:
Mwashasha is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

She has operated a beauty salon business for the past seven years; her potential customers are the neighboring community. Mwashasha faces a major challenge of the high cost of transportation in her business. She hopes to expand her business in the future.

With the 30,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase bundles of hair food oil, chemicals and hair weaves. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of hair food oil, chemicals and hair weaves

loans.name: Damira's Group

texts.en:
Damira was very overwhelmed when she found out about this loan from Kiva. This type of loan was exactly what she was recently looking for. Damira thinks it’s a sign from above for her to move forward with the help of Kiva  and believe in a better future.

Damira O., 56, is the leader of this group. She resides in the town of Toktogul, known for its large water reservoir. Recently, Damira became a widow and now lives all by herself. She is the mother of five grown children who live on their own now. Her youngest, a 19 year-old son works as a fireman in Chychkan Canyon.  He visits her occasionally and helps with taking care of the livestock. It’s been two years since Damira invested 5000 soms in purchasing two livestock animals. Despite her age and heavy physical load in her household, Damira is a very bright and optimistic woman. She looks at the world with a smile and positive thoughts. She is very thankful to her son, who offered his salary as a business start-up capital, because now the number of livestock she owns has grown dramatically. Besides devoting much time to livestock raising, Damira also works as a janitor in a local high school. Everyone who knows Damira just can’t stop admiring her love of life and desire to strive for a better life. These years of hard work has brought enough capital for her to organize a nice wedding ceremony for her son. The purpose of the loan is to purchase more livestock to increase this business.

 --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers, as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase livestock.

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Rosalie P. is from the town of Banga. She is 35 years-old. Rosalie is married and has two children aged 11 and two. To make a living, Rosalie owns and operates a business in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Rosalie works hard to build her business.

Rosalie joined Kiva partner CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalie has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Rosalie is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She has operated a café business for the past four years, operating from the market. Amina faces a major challenge of theft because of insecurity in the area. She hopes to expand and attract many customers in the future.

With the Kshs 25,000 she wants to purchase sacks of rice, beans, sugar and onions. She decided to work with Kiva partner Yehu to access loans to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of rice, beans, sugar and onions.

loans.name: Guljan's Group

texts.en:
It’s very important for a small community to have some infrastructure or business, because sometimes it can employ the basic percentage of a small community population.

Guljan K., 46 years-old, is the leader of this group. She is a resident of the coal-mining town of Tashkomur. Guljan’s family’s main occupation, like many others’ in the town is coal-mining. They feel lucky to be born in such a land rich for this natural resource. Guljan’s husband is a coal-miner in a local coalfield. Their house is situated not far from it, so this was the best option of business. Now it has been 20 years already and it’s a stable source of income for the family. He buys the best possible coal and then resells it to local residents and other towns. In winter time this is the main source of income for this family. In summer Guljan relies on cattle breeding as a key to financial stability for her family.  Cattle has also been one of the most prospective options for business. They own several heads of cattle and after raising them, resell them. The earnings of the family areapproximately 10 000 soms a month. Guljan would like to broaden her business and get a stabilized profit. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase vegetables for resale.

  --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers, as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy necessary construction supplies.

loans.name: Gulnarkan's Group

texts.en: This group consists of five ambitious individual entrepreneurs and colleagues. They are all involved in clothing retail and support each other in repaying the loan. Gulnarkan K., 50, is a leader of this group. She’s a resident of one of the five largest towns in the Jalalabad province. She lives with her husband, who is a private entrepreneur as a city cab driver, and with a 16-year-old daughter, who goes to high school. Gulnarkan has always been characterized by her friends and relatives as a person with a fighting spirit and a big desire to move forward. She says these precise features helped her to start up a women’s apparel retail business. Being a business-lady, she truly realizes the importance of the environment in business. She always hopes to have political and economic stability in Kyrgyzstan. This knowledge is due to her original profession in economics. Many years ago she used to work as an economist in a plant, but soon it stopped functioning and forced her to go into the business sphere. Six years ago, Gulnarakan spent 300,000 soms form the family budget to build a shop. She attaches high importance to how the shop looks and has decorated it carefully. Now she gains the fruits of her labor by 15,000 soms of monthly income. Gulnarkan applied for this loan with the belief that it’ll help her to increase her stock. The generated revenue will be spent on construction of a house. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To increase stock

loans.name: Perveen

texts.en:
Perveen is from Kasur, Pakistan, which is known for its tanneries. She has been living there in a four-room house in the area of Sheikh bhago for the past 10 years. Her husband’s name is M. S.; he is a daily wage laborer. At the age of 56, he finds that it is not easy to work, but he believes in hard work, which is why he is still very active and earns a reasonable profit every month. 

Perveen does embroidery work for clients in order to earn an income for her family. She is a talented lady who crafts beautiful embroidered designs on clothes. Her work attracts many customers. She utilizes her earnings to pay the utilities and to contribute to the financial needs of her family. 
  
She has seven children: five sons and two daughters. Perveen has transferred her knowledge and art of embroidery to her children. All of them except the youngest one do embroidery. The income from their embroidery work helps their parents with the financial responsibilities of the family. Her youngest son is studying in class 6th. Perveen is also a very good housewife and manages her household responsibilities very well.  

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her son M. akram. He wants to improve his embroidery business by purchasing embroidery materials, such as clothes, beads, and colored thread, in bulk. He has been operating this business for the past eight years. Perveen is confident that the loan will help him improve his business. Perveen regularly gets loans from Asasah, and this is her fifth loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained good credit behavior and never missed any meetings.

loans.use: To buy embroidery materials

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia is a married woman who lives in Calatrava, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating one business venture: pig fattening. Her husband Jose, who is 44 years old, works as a laborer to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities. They have nine children who are between 4 and 25 years old. Lucia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2009 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Lucia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 8,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 2,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000, which she intends to use as funds for her business operation so that she can continue to save for the future education of her children. Lucia is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org

loans.use: To fund her business operation

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty M. is from the village of New Calamba, Kalawit, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 30 years old.Betty is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Betty owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Betty has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Betty joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Betty has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Betty is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Betty from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

location.town: New Calamba, Kalawit, Zamboanga Del Norte

loans.name: Mavluda's Group

texts.en:
Our next creditor is a young mother with big ideas and ambitions but small opportunities. She believes in her potential to set her life on a new stage and a new path. 

Mavluda T., 25, is the leader of this group. She’s a resident of a very small town in the southern Kyrgyzstan, Nookat, with a population of over 13,000 people. She was born and grew up here and wants to spend the rest of her life here because she knows it’s the best place for her children. Mavluda’s husband Dastan is a successful musician and the main breadwinner of the family. 

They feel blessed to have two daughters of 5 and 3 years old. Last year when the kids were accepted to a daycare, Mavluda needed an occupation to devote her whole daytime. Being a mother has taught her good lessons of choosing the right products for her girls. So she ended up with the idea of selling children’s clothing. She can easily find common language with other mothers who look for the best clothing for their children. The business was started from 1, 000 soms taken from a family’s savings. For now Mavluda receives 7,500 soms of profit every month, most of which she puts back into goods circulation. Mavluda requested a loan from Kiva with intentions of satisfying her consumer needs. In the nearest future the family would like to renew the apartment lease.

       --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To meet her customer's needs and also help pay her lease.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is a single mother with one child who is still young for school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. 

She has operated a vegetable stall business for the past eight years, selling at the market to her neighbours. Esther faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation to her place of operation. She hopes to become a wholesaler of vegetables in the market in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase sacks of cabbages, onions, potatoes and mangoes for resell. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of cabbages, onions, potatoes and mangoes to resell.

loans.name: Anabelle

texts.en:
Anabelle G. is from the town of Surallah. She is 46 years old. Anabelle is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Anabelle owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Aside from farming, Anabelle also runs a sari-sari store where she sells various products. Anabelle dreams to be a successful businesswoman. 

Anabelle joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anabelle has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Anabelle is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure for her rice crops

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy necessary materials for her son's wedding

loans.name: Carlos

texts.en:
Carlos B. is from the town of Surallah. He is 41 years old. Carlos is married and has 4 children. To make a living, Carlos owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Carlos also raises chickens in his backyard. He is hoping to have a bigger poultry business. Carlos does his best to improve his family's living conditions.

Carlos joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carlos has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Carlos is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers and feeds.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and feeds

loans.name: Nasson

texts.en:
Nasson is a married man with one child who attends school. He lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

He has operated a game-playing station business at the market for the past four months. His potential customers are the neighboring community members. Nasson faces a major challenge of electricity power shortage in his business.  He hopes to improve his business to a high standard in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 he wants to purchase games and equipment. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase game-playing equipment for his arcade.

loans.name: Riaz

texts.en:
Riaz is a 27-year-old divorcee. Unfortunately, her marriage couldn’t last for long. She now lives with her 3 brothers. Riaz, along with her brothers, operates an embroidery business to fulfill the basic needs of the family. 

She has no children. She didn’t want to become burden on her brothers that’s why she started this business. She is excellent in her work and receives regular orders every month from her neighboring clients. She also does household work and makes the utmost effort to provide comfort to her family by fulfilling their needs. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her eldest brother whose name is Munnawar ali. He wants to buy embroidery material such as beads, colored thread and cloth because he has a larger order to fulfill due to marriage season. Riaz is very confident that her brother who is doing this business for past 10 years will successfully be able to improve its business condition after investing loan into it. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah, and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained good credit behavior and never missed any meetings.  

She lives in Kasur which is a small city of Punjab, Pakistan. It is famous for its leather industry. She lives there in a small home which contains 2 rooms, in the area of Sheikh Bhago.

loans.use: To buy embroider material for embroidery business

loans.name: Sourng

texts.en: Sourng S., 54, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. S. is a housewife while her husband is an accountant, earning an income of USD 8 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD 60 on food and USD 10 on the other necessary expenses. S. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to pay for the children’s school fees. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her third from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To pay for the children's school fee

loans.name: Celia

texts.en:
Celia L. is from the town of Surallah. She is 47 years old. Celia is married and has 3 children aged 20, 17 and 13. To make a living, Celia owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting  a variety of vegetables for sale. Celia also raises chickens in her backyard.

Celia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Celia has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Celia is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Zeinegul's Group

texts.en: Kyrgyz mountains and climate have always provided perfect conditions for farming and cattle breeding. Many residents believe that it’s a holy place to live. Zeinegul B., 38, is the leader of this group. Zeinegul, her husband and four kids live in the town of Tashkomur. Zeinegul has been raising cattle for ten years. This idea came from her parents who themselves were successful cattle breeders. The town of Tashkomur is a perfect place for domestic animals. Its high hills, fresh air and the cleanest spring water help Zeinegul raise very healthy livestock animals. Ten years ago she made her first steps in raising livestock by purchasing five goats. Since then the size of her assets has almost tripled. The result speaks for itself – Zeinegul and her husband bought a truck. Nowadays her husband’s work in the transportation services is a significant source of income for the family. The full income of the family is 15,000 soms a month. Unfortunately, sometimes it is barely enough to provide four kids with their basic needs. Zeinegul found out about this loan provided by Mol Bulak Finance and applied for it in order to buy some more cattle. Zeinegul’s dream is to build a big house so that her children will be very happy. ====================================== Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young and ambitious socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Eunice Achieng

texts.en:
Eunice has been in tailoring services for 25 years in Machakos town, and earns a profit margin of KES. 30,000. She is 49 years, married to Paul A., and they are blessed with two children who are already adults.


She was introduced to KADET LTD by a Credit Officer and she is applying for her first loan of KES. 50,000, which she intends to use to buy clothing materials and add one modern sewing machine.


In future she desires to grow her business and have financial stability.

loans.use: To buy clothing materials and add one sewing machine

loans.name: Hem

texts.en: Hem S., 60, is married and lives with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia – an area known for palm products. S. is a traditional doctor, earning $3 US per day to help cover the family's expenses. Each month, the family has to spend $50 US on food and $10 US on other expenses. S. is requesting a loan of $1000 US to purchase a new motorbike for family use. In the future, she would like to use additional income to repair her house. This will be her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for the family

loans.name: Mwanasiti

texts.en: Mwanasiti is a married woman with six children, four of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. For over twenty years, she has been selling fish at the market to her neighbours and passersby. Mwanasiti faces the major challenge of seasonality – during rainy season the supply of fish is low and demand is very high. With this 10,000 Kenyan shilling loan she wants to purchase bundles of fish for sale, cooking oil, salt and sacks of onions. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. She hopes to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of fish for sale, cooking oil, salt and sacks of onions

loans.name: Mob

texts.en:
Mob S. is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. S. sells food, earning an income of $10 per day to help cover the family expenses. 

Each month, the family has to spend $50 on food and $20 on the other necessary expenses. 

S. is requesting a loan of $1,200 to purchase a new motorbike for the family to use. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her third loan from CREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for family use

loans.name: Marn

texts.en:
Marn M., 44, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. 

M. is a housewife while her husband is a fisherman, earning an income of $19 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend $100 on food and $45 on the other necessary expenses. 

M. is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase fishing tools for her husband to improve his business. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her fifth loan from CREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy more fishing tools for her husband to improve the business

loans.name: Celsa

texts.en:
Celsa P. is from the town of Surallah. She is 51 years old, married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Celsa raises crops. Her main source of income comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. 

Celsa joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Celsa has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's tuition fees.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Nooran

texts.en:
Nooran is a talented lady. She runs an embroidery business from home to support her family financially. She makes embroidered clothes for neighborhood clients and earns a good income. She is a resident of Sheikh Bhago which is a small residential area of the city of Kasur. Kasur is known for its leather industry in Pakistan. She came to Kasur after her marriage. 

Nooran has two sons. Both of them have a shoe making business. Nooran couldn’t provide them with education due to poor financial conditions. Both of them are getting good results from their business and receiving regular orders from different shoe factories and shoe shops. Her elder son started this business four years ago and Nooran hopes that an investment will bring profitable changes to his business.  

Her husband’s name is N. A. and he has a construction supplies business. He has contracts with different construction companies and individuals. He has been doing this business for many years and is known for his good quality of construction materials. 

Nooran has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner Asasah for her elder son who wants to buy shoe laces, leather, nails and shoe polisher, etc., to make a larger quantity of shoes which will help him complete his orders on time and make more profit. She is a new loan user of Asasah and hopes that this will earn her son good profits and she will become a regular user.

loans.use: To buy shoe laces, leather, nails and shoe polisher for a shoe making business

loans.name: Heng

texts.en: Heng S., 55, is married and lives with her husband and two children in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia – an area known for palm products. S. is a housewife while her husband sells sugar cane juice earning $5 US per day to help cover the family's expenses. Each month, the family has to spend $80 US on food and $45 US on other expenses. S. is requesting a loan of $300 US to purchase more sugar canes to sell. In the future, she would like to use additional income to repair her house. This will be her fifth loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy more sugar cane

loans.name: Horn

texts.en: Horn S., 31, is married and lives with her husband and a child in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia – an area known for palm products. S. produces traditional baskets to sell, earning $2 US per day to help cover the family's expenses. Each month, the family has to spend $40 US on food and $15 US on other expenses. S. is requesting a loan of $500 US to purchase a new motorbike for family use. In the future, she would like to use additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for family use

loans.name: Morn

texts.en: Morn S., 34, is married and lives with her husband and a child in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia – an area known for palm products. S. sells groceries, earning $3 US per day to help cover the family's expenses. Each month, the family has to spend $50 US on food and $20 US on other expenses. S. is requesting a loan of $700 US to purchase more groceries to stock the store. In the future, she would like to use additional income to repair her house. This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to stock the store

loans.name: Tep

texts.en:
Tep S., 26, is married and resides with his wife and three children in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. S. is employed at a factory, earning an income of $2 per day to help cover the family expenses. 

Each month, the family has to spend $50 on food and $10 on the other necessary expenses. S. is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase a plot of farmland to grow more rice. In the future, he would like to use the additional income to repair his house. 

This will be his third loan from CREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy a plot of farmland

loans.name: El

texts.en: El K., 63, is married and lives with her husband and four children in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia – an area known for palm products. K. sells school stationary, earning $3 US per day to help cover the family's expenses. Each month, the family has to spend $100 US on food and $27 US on other expenses. K. is requesting a loan of $800 US to purchase a new motorbike for family use. In the future, she would like to use additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for family use

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is a widowed woman with three children, all of whom graduated from school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

She has operated a shortcake baking business for the past five years, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. Amina faces a major challenge of the high cost of transportation to her business. She hopes to become a big supplier of bread in the future.

With the 30,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase two bundles of wheat flour, one gallon of cooking oil, onions and salt. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase two bundles of wheat flour, one gallon of cooking oil, onions and salt

loans.name: Prak

texts.en:
Prak L. is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. L. is a traditional doctor, earning an income of $3 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend $100 on food and $10 on the other necessary expenses. 

L. is requesting a loan of $700 to pay for the children’s school fees. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her sixth loan from CREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: To pay for the children's school fees

loans.name: Elvira's Group

texts.en: Elvira J. is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Tashkomur, a small mining town in the south of Kyrgyzstan. She is 32 and divorced, so she brings up a 7-year-old son by herself. Her son studies at school. In order to earn money, Elvira works in the hospital; she is also engaged in livestock breeding. She applied for the loan in order to purchase animals for breeding. In the future, she dreams to purchase her own house and live independently from her parents. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

loans.name: Batmandakh

texts.en: Batmandakh is 30 years old and lives with his wife and son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His family lives in a small house, in the outer ger (nomadic housing tents) districts of the city. His son attends kindergarten, while his wife stays at home. Batmandakh supports his family by operating his small vacuum window-making factory. In 2001, he worked at another local window-making factory for two years. When he first began his business in 2003, he used to work with cheap and hand-operated tools. He had been running his business successfully, thus he bought new machinery and equipment. He is requesting a 3,500,000 Mongolian Tugriks (MNT) loan to purchase a better quality window-making machine and an electric saw. His business goal is to expand his factory’s size and employ more people. He wants to improve his business with this loan, and with the profits, be able to support his son’s education.

loans.use: To purchase window-making machinery and a saw

loans.name: Munnawar

texts.en:
Munnawar lives in Kasur, which is known for its tanneries. She has been living there in a two-room brick house in the area of Sheikh bhago for the past 20 years with her family. 

She has given birth to seven children: four sons and three daughters. None of them is able to get an education due to the poor financial conditions of their parents. Her two elder sons have a business of selling scrap while the others stay at home. 

Her husband’s name is M. S. and he deals in scrap as well as being involved in an animal-sales business. He buys animals in their early age and sells to butchers after raising them up. 

Munnawar herself is a housewife, preferring to stay at home and do her household works, but in her spare time, she also supports her husband by taking care of his animals. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s animal-sales business. With the loan, he will buy animals (goats) and increase his sales. He has 15 years of experience in his business and Munnawar is hopeful that an investment will bring even more profits to him. 

She is a new loan applicant of Asasah and she is confident that it will bring good financial changes to her husband’s business.

loans.use: To buy animals (goats) for an animal-sales business

loans.name: Mwanamvua

texts.en:
Mwanamvua is a married woman with five children, four of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. 

She has operated a retail business for the past one year, operating from home to sell to her neighbors and passersby. Mwanamvua faces a major challenge of the high cost of transportation in her business. She hopes to operate a wholesale shop in the future.

With the 25,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase two sacks of rice and coconuts for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase two sacks of rice and coconuts for sale

loans.name: Abbass

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 23 years old, married and has two children. In 2005, Abbass opened his own carpentry shop to improve his family's standard of living. He is well known in his area and has an excellent reputation. 

Abbass is requesting a $3000 loan to buy a new Italian machine for his business. He is planning to develop his work and skills so he can expand in the future.

loans.use: Buy a new Italian machine

loans.name: Baya

texts.en:
Baya is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. 

She has operated a fish selling business for the past one year, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. Baya faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She hopes to expand her business in the future.

With the 25,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase sacks of fish, cooking oil and salts. She decided to work with Yehu to access funds to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of fish, cooking oil and salts

loans.name: Tumurkhulug

texts.en: Tumurkhulug is 38 years old and lives with her husband and two sons in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She has been operating a retail jewelry stall at Narantuul, the biggest outdoor market in Mongolia, for 11 years. Her husband is a taxi driver and both of her sons attend public school. Her family lives in a small house, in the outer ger (Mongolian felt tent) districts of the city. She sells silver rings, necklaces, earrings and bracelets, which she purchases from a Turkish wholesale jewelry supplier. Since 2000, Tumurkhulug has been successfully running her business and with her profits, she built a new small house with a garage in 2007. Today she has 7,000,000 Mongolian Tugriks (MNT) in working capital. As Tumurkhulug has gained solid experience in past few years, she would like to improve her living and working conditions by increasing her working capital. She wants to expand her business in an indoor market instead of outdoors, since the working condition are affecting her health. She is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more jewelries. In the future, she wants to be able to run her business without any difficulties in an indoor market. She is ambitious and bright about her future and also, she hopes she can support her sons' education.

loans.use: To purchase more jewelries

loans.name: Zuhura

texts.en:
Zuhura is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water.

She has operated a retail business for one year, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She hopes to sell as a wholesaler in the future.

With the 15,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase five bundles of maize flour, sugar and rice. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase five bundles of maize flour, sugar and rice

loans.name: Mumtaz's Group

texts.en:
Mumtaz is 35 years old and married to R. M., who is a tailor master by profession. He runs a tailoring shop in the market, where he sews particularly men’s clothes. Due to his good stitching, he receives a good number of orders every month. 

She herself is a housewife; she prefers to stay at home and take care of her children. She is a very responsible person and fulfills her responsibilities very well. 

She is a resident of Faisalabad, which is a big city in Pakistan famous for its textile industry. She has lived there in the area of Yaseenabad with her family in a two-room brick house for past 15 years. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband, who wants to buy a new stitching machine because his old machine has become rough and doesn’t produce quality work; it also takes too much time to sew a single dress.
 
He has been doing this business for the past seven years and Mumtaz is hopeful that a new machine will help him finish his orders in less time and will earn him a better income. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her fourth loan application. In previous loan years, she has proved herself as a responsible client who never missed a single meeting and paid installments on time.

loans.use: To buy a new stitching machine for the tailoring business

loans.name: Ainura's Group

texts.en: Ainura E. is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Tashkomur, a small mining town in the south of Kyrgyzstan. She is 38 and married to a driver. Together they bring up four daughters. The two older daughters are at school and the others are not yet as they are preschool age (under 7). Ainura works as a teacher at school. In order to earn additional money for the family budget, she breeds livestock. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase four or five animals for breeding. In the future, she wants to enlarge a shed in order to keep more animals there. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

loans.name: Bano's Group

texts.en:
Bano lives in Faisalabad, Pakistan, which is famous for its textiles industry. She owns a two-room house there and has been living in it with her family for the past two years.
 
She is a 27-year-old business lady, selling cosmetics from her home. Her clients are mostly from her community. They give her orders for cosmetics, which enables her to earn well for her family.  

Besides her business, she also manages her household responsibilities very well and gives the required time to her family. She is married to M., who is a janitor with a meager income. Bano lives in a combined family with her brother-in-law, who has a construction supplies business. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the expansion of her cosmetics business. With the loan, she will buy cosmetics in a larger quantity, which will help her to fulfill orders on time and to increase her sales.  

She is a new loan user of Asasah and hopes that she will be able to achieve a better financial position in her business after the loan investment.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics for selling

loans.name: Myanzi Mixed Group-Mityana

texts.en:
Thirty-year-old Roset N. is happily married with three kids. It's now two years down the stretch for her food business in the Myanzi trading center market in Mityana. She has her own stall. Roset also has a charcoal sales enterprise that she operates. Roset says the persuasion of close friends gave her the motivation to take root in this business. 

Weekly, Roset says this business generates 14,000 shillings. With this loan, she says she is going to purchase more food to resell. Roset is affiliated with the Myanzi Mixed Group-Mityana.

loans.use: The purchase of more food to resell

loans.name: Mukadas' Group

texts.en: Mukadas K. is the leader of this group. She is 34 and lives in the south of Kyrgyzstan, in a small nice village called Nookat. Her husband went to work in Russia to earn money to cover their family needs. Mukadas takes care of four children: three sons and a daughter. All the children study at school. In order to contribute money to the family budget, Mukadas takes orders and sews Kyrgyz national clothes and dressmaking supplies. In this way, she earns 3,000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase fabrics and materials for sewing. In the future, she wants to save money and make house repairs. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics and materials

loans.name: Gulmira

texts.en:
Gulmira A. is 40 years old and widowed. She lives with her daughter’s family in Novonikolaevka village. 
In 1990, at the age of 20, Gulmira got married and became the mother of one daughter. Unfortunately, after seven years of happy marriage, her beloved husband died in car accident. In order to find means of subsistence for her small family, Gulmira started her business in cattle breeding. Using the money she had earned, in 2008 she bought a house in Novonikolaevka village with derelict grape bushes. As Gulmira had always dreamed to be engaged in land cultivating, she decided to revive a beautiful grape garden. Today, her garden consists of more than 200 bushes of grape in 11 different sorts. Such an assortment allows Gulmira to earn about more than 4,500 KGS in a month.  
Now, in order to buy chemicals to manure land and get the system flowing, Gulmira has applied for a loan of 50,000 KGS. With the revenues, she plans to scale up her cultivated land and enlarge the number of grape bushes. In the future, Gulmira wants to help her daughter buy a flat in Karabalta town. 
Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Micro-finance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of micro-finance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase chemicals to manure land

loans.name: Aptaiym's Group

texts.en:
Aptaiym K. is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Nookat, a small village in the south of Kyrgyzstan. She is 57 and married to a farmer. Together with her husband, she has raised seven children: four sons and three daughters. The daughters are married, the older sons work in Russia and the youngest son works in construction in Bishkek. In order to earn money to cover family expenses, Aptaiym cultivates agricultural products. She has been doing it for 25 years. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase fertilizers for farming.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Firas

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 24 years old and lives with three family members. In 2008, Firas opened his own wholesale and retail business for selling chicken. He is well known in his area and has an excellent reputation.

Firas is working on expanding his business by renting the shop next door. He is requesting $2400 loan to pay the rent expenses. He is aiming to increase his family's quality of life.

loans.use: To pay the rent expenses

loans.name: Gulisa's Group

texts.en:
Gulisa O. is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Kochkor, a small village in Isykul region. She is 50 and married to a farmer. She has three sons and two daughters. The older children are employed and the younger ones are students. In order to earn money, Gulisa takes orders and sews Kyrgyz national clothes and dressmaking supplies. Her husband is engaged in farming. He cultivates fruits and vegetables. With money received from the loan, the family wants to purchase a piece of land for farming.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase a piece of land for farming

loans.name: Kulmira's Group

texts.en:
Kulmira J. is the treasurer of this group. She is 49 and married. Her husband works in the Regional Electro Station. She has a son and a daughter, both students. Thirteen years ago, with the initial investment of 10,000 soms, Kulmira started to take orders and sew Kyrgyz national clothes, blankets and pillows. In this way, she earns 5,000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase sewing materials. In the future, she plans to repair the house.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics and materials

loans.name: Haidar

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 37 years old, married and has two children. One of his parents lives with his family and he is the only provider. In 2007, Haidar opened his own food market to improve his family's standard of living. He is well known in his community and has a good reputation.

Haidar is requesting a $2500 loan to renovate his shop. He wants to pave the shop and paint it. He is working on developing his business.

loans.use: To renovate the shop

loans.name: Ahmed

texts.en:
Ahmed is a young man from Rafah in Gaza Strip. Ahmed sells mobile phone accessories in his two-year-old shop. He sells phone covers, replaces broken screens, etc.

Ahmed wants to expand his business. He wants to include more services such as fixing phones. He took a loan from FATEN to purchase a wider variety and to be able to hire someone and buy tools to work on fixing phones.

Ahmed appears in the picture here in his store.

loans.use: To purchase mobile phone accessories to sell in the store

loans.name: Safar

texts.en:
Safar is a farmer. He lives with his family, including his wife and two little kids. His wife helps him care for their land. In the past, they have had problems in harvesting. They had to sell their crop in advance and see reduced earnings. By this time, Safar has gained a lot of experience in his business and now his crop is one of the most in-demand at the market. Safar now faces a small problem because his field is infertile, which makes it difficult to grow his crop. To solve this problem, he has decided to request a loan to buy seeds and fertilizers to support the field and make his crop more productive.   
 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase seed and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Gevorg

texts.en:
Gevorg I. is 32 years old and lives in Ijevan City with his wife and his two children.  Gevorg and his wife are accountants. In addition to his work as an accountant, in 2006 Gevorg started a workshop where he produces concrete slabs and stairs.  He sells most of what he produces to customers in Ijevan City, neighboring villages' building materials stores, and he also takes orders on site. 

Gevorg has a mixer, where he mixes sand, cement, and water. After mixing, he pours the concrete into special metal forms and then dries slabs in a natural way. Now Gevorg is asking for a 720,000 Armenian dram (AMD) loan to buy a dryer for the slabs, which will allow him to shorten the period of production time. Thanks to incomes from his cement block and slab business, Gevorg has been able to meet many of his family's financial needs.

loans.use: To buy a dryer for poured concrete slabs.

loans.name: Akmal

texts.en:
Akmal is a young energetic guy living with his parents. He has greenhouses where he grows wheat, onions and watermelon. Akmal has been in this business for five years. He enjoys working the land and providing people with high quality products. He keeps his greenhouses and household in order. He fixes things himself when something breaks. Akmal's father helps him in his business.

Akmal would like to borrow 7,500 Tajikistan somoni  to further equip his greenhouses and to buy seed and mineral fertilizer. He hopes to grow more crops this year and increase his family's income.
